title: Investigating Forecasting Models for Pandemic Infections Using Heterogeneous Data Sources: A 2-year Study with COVID-19
summary: This paper presents a two-year case study on COVID-19 forecasting in Cyprus, integrating a heterogeneous dataset including epidemiological data, vaccination records, policy measures, and weather conditions. The study aims to analyze infection trends, evaluate forecasting model performance, and assess the influence of external factors to enhance future pandemic preparedness and response strategies.

title: The nexus between disease surveillance, adaptive human behavior and epidemic containment
summary: This paper examines the complex feedback dynamics between disease surveillance, adaptive human behavior, and public health interventions in epidemic containment. It reveals that robust surveillance, by triggering early decentralized behavioral responses, can counter-intuitively lead to larger final epidemic sizes. The study emphasizes that minimizing epidemic impact hinges on a crucial trade-off between risk information dissemination and disease transmission, mediated by the surveillance system's triggering effect.

title: Including frameworks of public health ethics in computational modelling of infectious disease interventions
summary: This paper addresses the critical gap where computational models for infectious disease interventions often lack integrated ethical frameworks. It presents a proof-of-concept demonstrating how public health values like outcome equity and aggregate benefit can be incorporated into a simple vaccination model. The study reveals significant value trade-offs, showing that optimal intervention strategies can differ based on the prioritized ethical framework.

title: Artificial Intelligence for Infectious Disease Prediction and Prevention: A Comprehensive Review
summary: Artificial Intelligence (AI) and infectious diseases prediction have recently experienced a common development and advancement. Machine learning (ML) apparition, along with deep learning (DL) emergence, extended many approaches against diseases apparition and their spread. And despite their outstand...

title: Infectious Disease Forecasting in India using LLM's and Deep Learning
summary: This research paper proposes a novel framework for infectious disease forecasting in India, integrating deep learning algorithms with Large Language Models (LLMs). By analyzing historic disease spread data and climatic information spanning a decade, the study aims to predict the severity of future outbreaks, thereby enabling early detection and intervention to enhance public health resilience.

title: Disease Outbreak Detection and Forecasting: A Review of Methods and Data Sources
summary: This paper reviews existing standard methods for detecting and forecasting disease outbreaks, primarily focusing on approaches utilizing time series data. It examines both conventional public health surveillance data and novel, real-time data sources like social media and internet search engines, synthesizing research published between 2015 and 2022. The objective is to highlight methodologies that contribute to earlier detection and tracking of infectious diseases to mitigate their mortality impact.

title: Bayesian estimation of transmission networks for infectious diseases
summary: This paper introduces a Bayesian framework that integrates genomic and temporal data to accurately reconstruct infectious disease transmission networks. The model significantly improves upon existing methods by accounting for latent periods, differentiating between infection and symptom onset times, and allowing for multiple pathogen lineages. Simulation results confirm the model's reliability in estimating epidemiological parameters and network structure, along with its effectiveness in identifying direct transmission events.

title: Rebound in epidemic control: How misaligned vaccination timing amplifies infection peaks
summary: In this study, we explore the dynamic interplay between the timing of vaccination campaigns and the trajectory of disease spread in a population. Through comprehensive data analysis and modeling, we have uncovered a counter-intuitive phenomenon: initiating a vaccination process at an inopportune mom...

title: An early warning indicator trained on stochastic disease-spreading models with different noises
summary: This paper introduces a deep learning-based early warning indicator (EWI) for disease outbreaks, specifically designed to be robust against various noise sources (additive white, multiplicative environmental, demographic) and limited early-stage data. Trained on stochastic disease-spreading models incorporating these noises, the indicator effectively captures impending transitions in both simulated data and real-world COVID-19 cases, notably outperforming existing indicators. This advancement offers a promising tool for enhancing public health preparedness and response.

title: Wastewater-based Epidemiology for COVID-19 Surveillance and Beyond: A Survey
summary: The pandemic of COVID-19 has imposed tremendous pressure on public health systems and social economic ecosystems over the past years. To alleviate its social impact, it is important to proactively track the prevalence of COVID-19 within communities. The traditional way to estimate the disease preval...

title: Possible counter-intuitive impact of local vaccine mandates for vaccine-preventable infectious diseases
summary: This paper models the impact of local school-level vaccine mandates on vaccine-preventable diseases, showing a counter-intuitive effect. It reveals that if the population's vaccine coverage is near the herd-immunity level, such mandates can paradoxically increase the probability of outbreaks and the risk of infection for medically exempt pupils, primarily due to the relocation of unvaccinated individuals.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Vaccine Hesitancy on the Allocation of Vital Resources During COVID-19 Pandemic
summary: This paper proposes an enhanced SEIR compartmental model for COVID-19 that integrates the impact of vaccine hesitancy (VH), vaccination, and healthcare resource availability on disease dynamics. The authors use publicly available data to simulate various VH scenarios, demonstrating that reducing VH, ensuring adequate critical resources, and implementing timely vaccination programs significantly improve health outcomes and minimize fatalities.

title: Large-scale Long-tailed Disease Diagnosis on Radiology Images
summary: This paper introduces RadDiag, a foundational model for generalist radiology diagnosis capable of processing 2D and 3D images across diverse modalities and anatomies using a transformer-based fusion module. To address the scarcity of large-scale datasets, the authors compiled RP3D-DiagDS, a novel dataset of 40,936 cases covering 5,568 disorders from high-quality, clinician-reviewed online radiology images. RadDiag demonstrated strong performance, achieving 95.14% AUC internally and state-of-the-art results when applied zero-shot or fine-tuned on external hospital datasets.

title: The Effect of Vaccination on the Competitive Advantage of Two Strains of an Infectious Disease
summary: This paper investigates the competitive dynamics between two strains of an infectious disease, one more transmissible and the other more immune-resistant, under varying levels of natural and vaccine immunity. It demonstrates that vaccination significantly impacts which strain dominates a population, potentially causing dramatic shifts, and that the interplay between natural and vaccine immunity mechanisms determines which strain gains advantage as overall immunity increases.

title: Infectious disease surveillance needs for the United States: lessons from COVID-19
summary: This paper addresses the critical need to enhance infectious disease surveillance and forecasting systems in the United States, drawing lessons from the COVID-19 pandemic. It defines the requirements for an effective surveillance system to support evidence-based decision-making during pandemics, detailing necessary data elements, informing transmission-dynamic models, and considering health equity.

title: Integrative AI-Driven Strategies for Advancing Precision Medicine in Infectious Diseases and Beyond: A Novel Multidisciplinary Approach
summary: This paper introduces a novel multidisciplinary approach integrating artificial intelligence (AI) with diverse patient data, including genomics, proteomics, microbiomics, and clinical information, to advance precision medicine. Specifically focusing on infectious diseases and extendable to other complex conditions, the strategy aims to revolutionize disease management through precise diagnosis, personalized treatment, and proactive healthcare.

title: The Challenges and Opportunities in Creating an Early Warning System for Global Pandemics
summary: This paper advocates for the urgent creation of a global early warning system (EWS) for pandemics, citing lessons from COVID-19, the concerning dismantling of monitoring programs, and the exacerbating role of climate change on infectious diseases. It proposes an EWS that integrates diverse data sources (genomics, climate, social dynamics, healthcare infrastructure) with community-driven modeling and advanced AI to enable precision disease detection and accelerate science-informed public health policies globally. The authors illustrate the potential through the example of dengue fever in Brazil, framing such a system as intrinsic to sustainable development.

title: Modeling COVID-19 Transmission using IDSIM, an Epidemiological-Modelling Desktop App with Multi-Level Immunization Capabilities
summary: This paper introduces IDSIM, a native Windows desktop application developed by Ontario Tech University and the Durham Region Health Department, designed for in-house epidemiological modeling of infectious diseases, particularly COVID-19. The app utilizes a multi-stratified compartmental model to simulate various virus variants, vaccination levels, and public health measures. Key findings include the necessity of both natural and vaccination-induced immunity for Delta variant herd immunity, the impact of waning immunity on achieving it, and predictions for an Omicron wave's significant challenges and peak timing based on booster dose administration.

title: Sensitivity analysis in an Immuno-Epidemiological Vector-Host Model
summary: This paper introduces a novel immuno-epidemiological vector-host model that integrates within-host virus-immune system interactions with population-level disease dynamics. By applying Sensitivity Analysis to this multi-scale model, the study quantifies the significant impact of immunological parameters, such as within-host pathogen growth rate, on epidemiological outcomes like R0 and host infectiousness. The findings underscore the potential importance of control strategies targeting within-host pathogen reduction for mitigating disease prevalence.

title: Modelling the Effect of Vaccination and Human Behaviour on the Spread of Epidemic Diseases on Temporal Networks
summary: This paper introduces a mathematical model on time-varying networks to simulate the spread of recurrent epidemic diseases in partially vaccinated populations, incorporating factors like differential vaccine effectiveness, testing, NPIs, isolation, and human behavior. Utilizing a mean-field approach, the study analytically derives the epidemic threshold and endemic prevalence, revealing that while vaccination mitigates severe illness, it can paradoxically favor resurgent outbreaks in certain scenarios, underscoring the ongoing need for rigorous testing, public cautiousness, and potential NPI reintroduction.

title: Unlocking capacities of viral genomics for the COVID-19 pandemic response
summary: This paper highlights the unprecedented generation of SARS-CoV-2 genomic data during the COVID-19 pandemic and emphasizes the critical role of viral genomics, combined with bioinformatics, in public health. It discusses how these tools are essential for tracking variant spread, reconstructing epidemic dynamics, and informing timely public health responses and interventions for current and future infectious disease threats.

title: Modeling the COVID-19 pandemic: A primer and overview of mathematical epidemiology
summary: This paper provides a comprehensive review of mathematical epidemiological models utilized during the COVID-19 pandemic, outlining the theoretical foundations and extensions of Kermack-McKendrick type models. It analyzes how these models address critical public health questions, including transmission heterogeneity, non-pharmaceutical interventions, vaccine strategies, and viral evolution, while also critically evaluating their properties, findings, and inherent deficiencies.

title: Population-scale testing can suppress the spread of infectious disease
summary: This paper proposes a strategy for rapidly controlling and potentially eradicating human-to-human transmitted infectious diseases through repeated, population-scale testing and isolation of infected individuals. It demonstrates, via rigorous analysis and simulations, that a sufficient testing rate can reduce the basic reproduction number below 1.0, leading to epidemic collapse, regardless of strong assumptions about test accuracy or compliance.

title: Controlling infectious diseases: the decisive phase effect on a seasonal vaccination strategy
summary: This paper investigates the chaotic dynamics observed in seasonally forced Susceptible-Infected-Recovered (SIR) epidemic models, which reflect the unpredictable fluctuations of common infectious diseases. It proposes and demonstrates the effectiveness of a phase control technique, interpreted as a weak perturbation on a seasonal vaccination strategy, to suppress this chaos and convert unpredictable motions into regular ones. The study highlights the crucial role of the phase difference between seasonal contact rates and vaccination efforts in achieving stable disease dynamics.

title: Optimal vaccination program for two infectious diseases with cross immunity
summary: The paper investigates optimal vaccination strategies for two infectious diseases exhibiting cross immunity, competing for resources within the same population. Utilizing a two-layer Susceptible-Infected-Removed (SIR) model, the authors identify three distinct scenarios for optimal vaccination programs aimed at preventing outbreaks of both diseases at minimum cost. A crucial analytical criterion, based on the costs of the respective vaccines, is derived to specify the most effective program.

title: Antibiotic treatment, duration of infectiousness, and disease transmission
summary: This paper challenges the conventional view that antibiotic treatment always reduces disease transmission, proposing that by suppressing within-host pathogen density, antibiotics can relax the overall rate of host removal from infectious status (e.g., recovery, isolation, mortality). Through a deterministic modeling approach, the study identifies conditions where this mechanism can paradoxically increase the duration of a host's infectiousness and, consequently, elevate the expected number of new infections.

title: IoT Platform for COVID-19 Prevention and Control: A Survey
summary: This survey paper proposes and demonstrates a potential fog-cloud combined Internet of Things (IoT) platform for systematic and intelligent COVID-19 prevention and control, addressing the need for long-term non-pharmaceutical interventions against the unprecedented pandemic. It investigates and reviews state-of-the-art literature across five critical interventions: Symptom Diagnosis, Quarantine Monitoring, Contact Tracing & Social Distancing, Outbreak Forecasting, and SARS-CoV-2 Mutation Tracking, highlighting IoT's capabilities.

title: Medical Imaging and Computational Image Analysis in COVID-19 Diagnosis: A Review
summary: This review paper examines automated methods for COVID-19 diagnosis using medical imaging, analyzing the disease's characteristics in images and the accuracy of AI-based approaches. It concludes that medical imaging can reveal early COVID-19 signs, even in asymptomatic patients, and automated machine learning methods offer high accuracy while reducing diagnostic time, cost, and error.

title: Dynamics of epidemic diseases without guaranteed immunity
summary: This paper introduces a novel epidemiological model addressing diseases like SARS-CoV-2, where immunity post-recovery is not guaranteed but contingent on sustained infection. Utilizing field theory, the model defines distinct disease dynamics phases and accurately describes the Wuhan COVID-19 outbreak, suggesting only 30% of recovered individuals developed immunity. The findings offer a framework for public health decision-making to prevent pandemic escalation.

title: Beyond just "flattening the curve": Optimal control of epidemics with purely non-pharmaceutical interventions
summary: This paper presents an optimal control strategy for managing epidemics using purely non-pharmaceutical interventions (NPIs) when vaccines and treatments are unavailable and complete eradication is impossible. Utilizing an extended SEIR model and optimal control theory, the strategy aims to minimize disease-related deaths and socio-economic costs while simultaneously establishing sufficient natural immunity to prevent a second wave. The numerically computed optimal control is a single, intensive intervention scenario that requires a delicate balance between control efficacy, economic burden, and the risk of resurgence.

title: Severity Detection Tool for Patients with Infectious Disease
summary: This paper presents a proof-of-principle for an automated severity detection tool designed to identify autonomic nervous system dysfunction (ANSD) levels in patients with infectious diseases like Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) and tetanus. Leveraging machine learning on physiological data (ECG, PPG) from low-cost wearable sensors, the tool extracts novel features and uses a Support Vector Machine, demonstrating encouraging classification performance and outperforming standard Heart Rate Variability (HRV) analysis.

title: Coupling the circadian rhythms of population movement and the immune system in infectious disease modeling
summary: This research introduces a stochastic metapopulation model to investigate how the coupled circadian rhythms of human mobility and the immune system influence infectious disease dynamics. The study finds that these synchronized circadian patterns generally constrain the pace and extent of disease emergence, suggesting that strategic adjustments to daily routines, such as shifting commuting times, could mitigate outbreaks.

title: Geographically-dependent individual-level models for infectious diseases transmission
summary: This paper introduces Geographically-Dependent Individual-Level Models (GD-ILMs), an extension of existing discrete-time individual-level models (ILMs), to incorporate the effect of spatial location itself on infectious disease transmission, rather than just spatial separation. These models allow for the evaluation of spatially varying risk factors and unobserved spatial structure using a Conditional Autoregressive (CAR) model, aiming to formulate etiological hypotheses and identify high-risk geographical regions.

title: A Data-Validated Host-Parasite Model for Infectious Disease Outbreaks
summary: This paper develops a data-validated mathematical model for host-parasite dynamics using the guppy-Gyrodactylus turnbulli system, a quantifiable model for infectious diseases. It estimates the basic reproduction number (R0) for this system and identifies parasite growth rate and host immune response rate as critical factors influencing outbreak peak and timing. These findings highlight the importance of host resistance and parasite virulence in disease control strategies.

title: Early Detection of Influenza outbreaks in the United States
summary: This paper introduces a multivariate algorithm utilizing freely available online data (Google search and Wikipedia pageviews) for early detection of influenza outbreaks in the US. It demonstrates that a specific combination of eight such time series can provide significantly earlier warnings than traditional surveillance, predicting seasonal influenza activity an average of 16.4 weeks ahead and recognizing the 2009 H1N1 pandemic five weeks in advance of CDC thresholds.

title: Supervised learning improves disease outbreak detection
summary: This paper introduces the first supervised learning approach, based on hidden Markov models (HMMs), for infectious disease outbreak detection using routinely collected public health surveillance data. The model significantly improves upon state-of-the-art methods by reducing the false positive rate by up to 50% while maintaining equivalent sensitivity, as demonstrated with real Salmonella and Campylobacter data and simulations. This represents a crucial advancement in leveraging machine learning for more effective public health surveillance.

title: The need for an integrative thinking to fight against emerging infectious diseases
summary: This paper presents the proceedings of the 5th seminar on emerging infectious diseases (EIDs), outlining seven priority proposals for an integrative approach to combat these threats. The key recommendations span enhanced research for prediction and early detection, strengthening surveillance of zoonotic transmission in high-risk areas, improving local health infrastructure and public awareness, optimizing patient care, and reforming governance and economic strategies.

title: Global stability of epidemic models with imperfect vaccination and quarantine on scale-free networks
summary: This paper introduces and rigorously analyzes two novel epidemic models (SVIQR and SVIQS) on scale-free networks, incorporating variable population size, degree-related imperfect vaccination, and quarantine. It investigates their basic reproduction number, global stability of equilibria, and bifurcation behaviors using diverse mathematical techniques and validates them with stochastic simulations, providing insights for public health planning.

title: Early warning signals in plant disease outbreaks
summary: This research introduces a lattice-based epidemic model with a stochastic component to study disease spread in host populations, identifying a critical transition between localized containment and widespread outbreaks. The study successfully applies early-warning indicators, derived from dynamical systems theory, to forecast these critical shifts before the onset of an epidemic. This methodology demonstrates a promising approach for predicting infectious disease outbreaks using computational models.

title: Infection-acquired versus vaccine-acquired immunity in an SIRWS model
summary: This paper analyzes an SIRWS epidemiological model to investigate the impact of differing durations between infection-acquired and vaccine-acquired immunity on infectious disease dynamics, particularly in the context of pertussis re-emergence. It reveals that such differences can induce cyclic behavior, alter overall transmission patterns, and significantly influence long-term disease prevalence, challenging conventional assumptions about high vaccine coverage.

title: On the predictability of infectious disease outbreaks
summary: This research investigates the fundamental information-theoretic limits to predicting infectious disease outbreaks, using permutation entropy as a model-independent measure. The study identifies an inherent "entropy barrier" to forecasting time series data for various diseases but finds that this barrier often extends beyond the typical duration of single outbreaks. This suggests that outbreaks are generally predictable within their relevant timescales, though the specific forecast horizon varies by disease due to factors like changing transmission dynamics and social network heterogeneity.

title: Mind the scales: Harnessing spatial big data for infectious disease surveillance and inference
summary: This paper explores the growing utility of spatial big data, characterized by its velocity, volume, variety, and geographic information, in enhancing infectious disease surveillance and epidemiological inference. It reviews current applications, identifies opportunities for improving public health coordination and disease mitigation, and critically examines the associated technical, practical, and ethical challenges. Ultimately, the work discusses the broader implications for health risk communications, multi-scale public health coordination, and policy recommendations.

title: A generalized-growth model to characterize the early ascending phase of infectious disease outbreaks
summary: This paper introduces a novel 2-parameter generalized-growth model designed to accurately characterize the early ascending phase of infectious disease outbreaks, accommodating a spectrum of epidemic profiles from sub-exponential to exponential growth. By applying this model to 20 diverse real-world outbreaks, the study revealed significant variability in growth patterns, establishing sub-exponential growth as a prevalent phenomenon. These findings underscore the importance of considering 'deceleration parameters' to enhance the accuracy of mathematical transmission models and improve disease forecasting.

title: Molecular Infectious Disease Epidemiology: Survival Analysis and Algorithms Linking Phylogenies to Transmission Trees
summary: This paper introduces a rigorous statistical framework combining survival analysis and phylogenetic data to more efficiently estimate generalizable disease transmission parameters. It establishes a one-to-one correspondence between phylogenetic interior node host assignments and epidemiologically consistent transmission trees, developing algorithms to leverage this for improved likelihood calculations and hazard ratio estimation. The methodology, validated by simulation and applied to a foot-and-mouth disease outbreak, emphasizes the crucial, often overlooked, role of data from individuals who escape infection.

title: Introduction to statistical inference for infectious diseases
summary: This paper offers an introduction to statistical inference for infectious diseases, commencing with the general stochastic epidemic model. It outlines methods for inferring critical parameters such as the basic reproduction number ($R_0$) and vaccination coverage ($v_c$) from diverse outbreak data, considering individual heterogeneities and heterogeneous mixing. The paper also provides an overview of statistical techniques for parameter estimation and addresses the challenge of early outbreak detection in surveillance.

title: Indirect transmission and the effect of seasonal pathogen inactivation on infectious disease periodicity
summary: This paper presents a mathematical model exploring indirect transmission of infectious diseases via an environmental pathogen reservoir, highlighting the critical role of the pathogen lifespan to infectious state duration ratio in determining disease dynamics. It demonstrates that a seasonally forced pathogen inactivation rate introduces a time delay between peak environmental pathogen survival and peak disease incidence, with the observed periodicity matching the seasonal forcing and being independent of acquired immunity.

title: Spatial dynamics of airborne infectious diseases
summary: This paper presents an epidemiological model to analyze the spatial dynamics of airborne infectious diseases, focusing on droplet transport by diffusive and convective processes in indoor environments. It reveals that larger droplets (~4 μm) are primary drivers of infection spread, while smaller droplets (~0.4 μm) and diffusion are inefficient modes of transmission. Crucially, the study identifies a threshold air velocity that can effectively impair disease transmission, even when the basic reproduction number R0 exceeds unity.

title: Modelling the strategies for age specific vaccination scheduling during influenza pandemic outbreaks
summary: Finding optimal policies to reduce the morbidity and mortality of the ongoing pandemic is a top public health priority. Using a compartmental model with age structure and vaccination status, we examined the effect of age specific scheduling of vaccination during a pandemic influenza outbreak, when t...

title: The Impact of Past Epidemics on Future Disease Dynamics
summary: This paper investigates the long-term dynamics of seasonal epidemics in populations with heterogeneous contact networks and varying levels of acquired immunity. It develops two mathematical models using percolation theory to show how past outbreaks restructure the susceptible host population, thereby limiting the potential for future epidemics, and speculates on evolutionary pressures for increased pathogen infectiousness.

title: Profiling of a network behind an infectious disease outbreak
summary: This paper introduces a novel method to reverse-engineer the underlying network topology and transmission parameters driving infectious disease outbreaks. By employing stochastic differential equations within a meta-population framework and maximal likelihood estimation on early growth phase data, it can uncover the effectively decisive network structure and epidemiological parameters. The method's efficacy was demonstrated using both synthetic datasets and real-world data from the SARS outbreak.
